title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHICAGO — In the final moments of a brutal, defensive war, the Chicago Bulls needed a miracle. With the shot clock dead and the season hanging in the balance, they put the ball, and their fate, into the hands of the only man who could author such a finish: Michael Jordan.

In a game defined by grit and physicality, Jordan’s transcendent 45-point performance was the sole offensive constant, culminating in a game-winning shot that lifted the Bulls to an 88-87 victory over the defiant New York Knicks. On a night where no other Bull scored more than Luc Longley’s 11 points, Jordan’s brilliance was not just a highlight; it was the entire story.

The Knicks, led by Patrick Ewing’s 21 points and 11 rebounds, threw everything they had at His Airness. The game was a rock fight, a 48-minute grind where every possession was a battle. But Jordan was simply operating on a different plane. While his teammates struggled to find their rhythm, he waged a one-man war against the entire Knicks defense, slicing to the rim and hitting impossible jumpers.

With the score tied in the final seconds, the play was simple: get the ball to number 23. Jordan drove, absorbed the contact, and let fly a hanging jumper that found nothing but net as the buzzer sounded. The United Center erupted.

It was more than a game-winning basket; it was a historic exclamation point on a legendary 45-point playoff masterpiece, a performance that reminded everyone why, when the lights are brightest, there is Michael Jordan, and then there is everyone else.
